message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of Hexosaminidase A activity in the blood suggests Tay-Sachs disease, which is known to cause a cherry red spot on fundoscopic examination. Papilledema is associated with increased intracranial pressure, cotton wool spots are associated with hypertension or diabetes, and Hollenhorst plaque is a cholesterol embolus in the retinal arterioles, which is uncommon in infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of Hexosaminidase A activity suggests Tay-Sachs disease, which causes a cherry red spot in the macula. None of the other options are associated with this disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and family history suggest Tay-Sachs disease, a lysosomal storage disorder. The absence of hexosaminidase A activity confirms the diagnosis. The characteristic finding on fundoscopic examination is a cherry-red spot at the macula due to accumulation of material in the ganglion cells. Papilledema, cotton wool spots, and Hollenhorst plaque are associated with vascular and pressure-related changes in the eye, which are not relevant to Tay-Sachs disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of Hexosaminidase A activity and the symptoms suggest Tay-Sachs disease, which is likely to present with a cherry-red spot on fundoscopic examination. Papilledema is associated with increased intracranial pressure, while cotton wool spots and Hollenhorst plaques are associated with arterial occlusion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and family history suggest Tay-Sachs disease, which is characterized by a cherry red spot on the macula of the eye. Papilledema, cotton wool spots, and Hollenhorst plaque are not associated with Tay-Sachs disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of Hexosaminidase A activity and the symptoms suggest Tay-Sachs disease, which is characterized by a cherry red spot on fundoscopic examination. Papilledema, cotton wool spots, and Hollenhorst plaque are not associated with Tay-Sachs disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of Hexosaminidase A activity and the family history are suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease, which is known to cause a cherry red spot on the macula when seen on fundoscopic examination. None of the other options are associated with Tay-Sachs disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and family history suggest Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by a deficiency in hexosaminidase A. An ophthalmologic examination will reveal a cherry red spot. The other options are not associated with this disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of weakness and seizures in a child with consanguineous parents, along with the absence of hexosaminidase A activity, suggest Tay-Sachs disease. The classic ophthalmologic finding in Tay-Sachs disease is a cherry red spot on the macula. None of the other options are associated with Tay-Sachs disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and family history suggest a diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of hexosaminidase A. A characteristic finding in the retina of patients with Tay-Sachs disease is a cherry red spot, which is due to the accumulation of lipids in the macula. Papilledema, cotton wool spots, and Hollenhorst plaque are findings typically associated with hypertensive retinopathy.
